advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (SEPT. 1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"The amazing TI-99/4A.<br> A computer for 1800fr"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> LEAFLET #2</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH BROCHURE FRONT</strong></font><br><blockquote>Description of the complete Atmos system.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Jacques Sorro</b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1979)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> SANCO BROCHURE #2</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> HP BROCHURE</strong></font><br><blockquote>Extract of an HP sales brochure describing the models of the HP 9000-200 series.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>Einstein's face probably means: Buy a ZX-81 and you will become a new genius...<p class="petitgris">Karl_Heinz - www.sharpmz.org</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (JULY 1985)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"The new Laser 3000" <br><br> "At last, un complete PRO system with disk drive for 4980 F"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>''Each day, go on the computing road''</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (SEPT. 1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> STUPID PICTURE #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>The same women has changed its shirt... But hey, what's the message behind this pictures ? Would it be that it's sexy to work on an Alpha Plus, or that women prefer men owning an Alpha Plus ?!</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN BROCHURE #3</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Volken </b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ONTEL ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1978 BROCHURE #3</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FIRST ADVERT (1989)</strong></font><br><blockquote>This brochure was jointly published by Philips and American Interactive Media (the Philips/PolyGram joint venture that was set up to develop CD-i consumer software prior to the launch of the hardware). It was intented to give a general overview of CD-i's functionality in a consumer area. The brochure was presented to visitors of multimedia fairs and business partners at around 1989. The CD-i unit (including the remote control) that is displayed is an artist's impression of a player, it was never actually produced. The first consumer CD-i player, the CDI 910, appeared on the market in the US in October 1991. <br><br> <font color="#666666">Source = <a href="http://www.icdia.org/" target="_blank">The New International CD-i Association</a></font><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.icdia.org/" target="_blank">The New International CD-i Association</a> for this picture.</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> NEWBURRY BROCHURE #3</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b>www.oldcomputers.freeserve.co.uk </b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. AD #1 (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>The HHC advertising campain was not really attractive: black & white, lots of small characters texts, small pictures...</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE AD</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Jun Suzuki <a href="http://member.nifty.ne.jp/tarucus/museum/cool/cool.htm">web site</a></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (FEBRUARY 1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"the power of words depends on the way you use them"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (DEC.1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.K. ADVERT (1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ARABIC MODEL</strong></font><br><blockquote>In late 1988, bilingual (arab / french) versions of the TO-7/70 were sold for peanuts. These models could display latin and arabic characters. The keyboard was also bilingual, as well as the Basic !</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> DECEMBER 1972 HP JOURNAL</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Courtesy <b>Joe Rigdon</b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMOTIONAL PICTURE #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Learn computing today to be ready for tomorrow"</blockquote>

computer.description:
The Enterprise 64 was a very long-awaited computer, two years between its announcement and its marketing! It changed its name a lot of times: its first name was Elan 64, then Flan, lastly Enterprise.
It has great features, which wasn't found on all other home computers, like its interfaces, great graphics and sounds capacities provided by two special custom chips called "Nick" and "Dave".
The BASIC Interpreter is supplied on a ROM cartridge and can be easily replaced with any other language. This BASIC is a very powerful structured basic with great graphic commands and can store several programs simultaneously in RAM. It has a small word processing in ROM and up to 32 computers can be linked together.
But despite its great characteristics and all its interfaces, the Enterprise 64 was a flop in the marketplace.
Several months later, a new model was launched: the Enterprise 128, which was nothing more than an Enterprise 64 with 128 KB RAM. Unsold stocks of these systems (nearly all :-)), were sold to East-Europeans countries, and especially Hungary where it met great success. Thus, most nowadays Enterprise activity comes from here. _______________________

emulator.description: Free, portable emulator of the Enterprise 128 with C sources
emulator.name: EP128EMU

emulator.description: ep32 is a heavily modified version of kevin thacker's ENTER emulator
emulator.name: ep32

emulator.description: This multi-system emulator, can emulate the Enterprise. Project is in VERY early stage at the moment (May 2003).
emulator.name: NEMESYS (NEw Machine Emulator SYStem)

emulator.description: New emulator for 32bits OS, currently (july 2001) in early development phase
emulator.name: Penelope

computer.graphics: Eight graphic modes, max : 672 x 512 (2 col), most used : 256 x 160 (16 col)
computer.keyboard: Complete keyboard with function keys and built-in joystick
computer.name: Enterprise 64 / 128
computer.ports: RGB Video / Audio output, Expansion port, Tape Interface, Joystick (2), Cardridge slot, RS432 (Serial/Net), TV output, Power input, Printer

shot.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> ENTERPRISE 64</strong></font><br><blockquote>On top of its advanced features the Enterprise had a nice design and good quality keyboard, even if one can reproach a little 'toyish' feel for the keyboard and joystick.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ENTERPRISE 128</strong></font><br><blockquote>Little riddle: Apart from the Enterprise label, what is the only external difference between an Enterprise 64 and a 128?<br> See the next picture... </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> BOTH MODELS</strong></font><br><blockquote>So, the only difference is... the joystick cap color ;-) Green for the 64, grey for the 128. <br><br> In fact there is another difference between these two models, the 128 has a German keyboard, The 64 is a UK version.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> SIDES VIEW</strong></font><br><blockquote>Notice the expansion connector on the right side, intended for the (vaporware?) dual floppy drive unit, and the ROM cartridge slot on the left side.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> CLOSE-UP</strong></font><br><blockquote>The joystick replaces arrow keys in the Basic editor and wordprossor, it seems to be a bit fragile for action games though.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> REAR CONNECTORS</strong></font><br><blockquote><b><font color="blue">(1)</font></b> Reset switch<br> <b><font color="blue">(2-3)</font></b> Joystick connectors<br> <b><font color="blue">(4)</font></b> printer connector<br> <b><font color="blue">(5)</font></b> Serial or network connector<br> <b><font color="blue">(6)</font></b> Jacks allowing to connect up to 2 tape recorders<br> <b><font color="blue">(7)</font></b> RGB output connector<br> <b><font color="blue">(8)</font></b> TV aerial jack<br> <b><font color="blue">(9)</font></b> External AC adaptor jack.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> 64'S MAINBOARD</strong></font><br><blockquote>The delay in the Enterprise launch was primarily due to design difficulties with the two custom circuits which provide the Entreprise with powerful graphic and sound features. The general design of the unit is of good quality.<br><br> <b><font color="blue">(1)</font></b> First custom IC, called Nick, from its designer's name. Controls the powerful graphic features. A rudimentary heat sink covers it<br> <b><font color="blue">(2)</font></b> Second custom IC, called Dave. Manages 4 sound channels and 8 octaves.<br> <b><font color="blue">(3)</font></b> Expansions port, mainly intended to connect the (vaporware ?) double floppy drive unit<br> <b><font color="blue">(4)</font></b> 32 KB ROM chip. Holds the Wordprocessor program<br> <b><font color="blue">(5)</font></b> Z80-A microprocessor running at 4 Mhz, here a SGS version<br> <b><font color="blue">(6)</font></b> 64 Kb. RAM, stored in eigth 4164 chips (64000 cells x 1 bit)<br> <b><font color="blue">(7)</font></b> Keyboard connectors. Notice also the smal loudspeaker, fortunately, an Hi-Fi sound output connector is provided<br> <b><font color="blue">(8)</font></b> ROM cartridge connector, mainly used by the Basic language cartridge.<br> <b><font color="blue">(9)</font></b> Power regulators heat sink. </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> 128'S MAINBOARD</strong></font><br><blockquote>The mainboard is exactly the same as the 64 version, a piggy-back 64 KB RAM expansion card has simply been added. </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> MANUALS</strong></font><br><blockquote>Installation, IS-BASIC and wordprocessor manuals, and IS-BASIC cartridge.</blockquote>
